events.summary: Pantaleón Enrique Joaquín Granados Campiña was born, marking the arrival of a future musical genius and piano virtuoso. Little did his parents know they were just one toddler tantrum away from perplexing concert halls around the world.
Granados began his piano studies in Barcelona. It was like musical kindergarten where he learned to tickle the ivories from teachers who probably hoped he wouldn't just play Chopsticks.

Moved to Paris for further studies, where he took private lessons with a renowned professor. Although he couldn't get into the conservatoire, he certainly was a 'private student' and made the most of it, probably impressing the French with his Catalan charm.
Granados returned to Barcelona, bringing back a suitcase full of French sophistication and a few extra musical skills, setting the stage for a thriving career ahead.
His opera María del Carmen debuted to much acclaim, winning the attention of King Alfonso XIII. It was the kind of royal reception every composer dreams of, minus the tiaras.

Winning a national competition for his concert piece Allegro de concierto brought Granados into the spotlight, proving he could not only play the piano but also make it sing for him (or at least make the judges dance with joy).
The suite Goyescas premiered and sent the audience into a frenzy. It was like a musical painting; patrons were pretty much dancing through the gallery of sounds inspired by Francisco Goya's work!
The opera version of Goyescas debuted in New York City to rave reviews, making Granados the toast of the town. Nothing like a little transatlantic success to make one's heart swell!
Before his untimely death, Granados treated audiences to a final recital and made live player piano recordings. You could say he went out with a bang—or perhaps a symphony!

Granados drowned after the ferry he was on was torpedoed during World War I. A romantic hero, he made the ultimate sacrifice for love, refusing to forsake his wife in a moment of chaos – a true testament to his character!

compositions.title: Jota de Miel de la Alcarria
Piano Quintet in G minor, Op.49
